p.s: The extract from Act I of the play Clybourne Park, written by Bruce Norris and published in 2011, is about a heated discussion between Karl and Russ about several reasons why the black family should move into the house of Russ and Bev and why not.
Russ's opinion about the Clybourne Park community seems to be divided.
He claims that every time he and his wife are going grocery shopping or for a haircut, they are watched suspiciously from other community members for no reason (cf. ll. 101-111).
Additionally the community did not even support or prevented his son from going to the Korean war (cf. ll. 119-137).
When Karl exits through the open door again, he wants to go on with the discussion.
He seems to found a new argument he persistentspersists on (cf. ll. 70-77).
Furthermore he claims that he has the responsibility for the community and wants to defend their opinions (cf. ll. 98-90).
He probably wants to provoke Russ as well and consistconsists on his arguments.
Russ however reacts aggressively, just wants Karl to leave the house, because his opinion does not matter for Russ.
He tries to calm down and ends up talking about the way the community treats his family (cf. ll. 101ff.).
